content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player who is comfortable with taking risks, I would reason that the game offers two main scenarios:

1. If my opponent always picks R (the strategy dominating my B), they will earn 35$ for every round I choose B and nothing if I pick R. In this case, I would lose a significant amount of money in the long run by playing B consistently. On the other hand, choosing R would give me a higher payoff in most rounds (45$ vs 0$), but I would also miss out on the smaller 40$ payoff for matching their choice when they pick B.
2. If my opponent is smart and tries to exploit my preference for taking risks by always picking B, I will get the higher payoffs in most rounds by playing R (45$ vs 35$). However, if my opponent occasionally switches to R as well, I can still earn 40$ by matching their choice. In this scenario, it would be beneficial to deviate from a purely risk-seeking strategy and consider mixing up my choices to maximize earnings.

Considering the unpredictability of my opponent's choices and the potential for them to adapt to my preferred strategy, I will attempt to employ a mixed strategy in this game. By varying my choice between R and B throughout the 75 rounds, I aim to capitalize on both the higher payoff offered by R (45$) and the consistent smaller payoff of B (40$).

{R or B, depending on the round number and potential opponent's strategy adaptation}
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I have already learned that my opponent prefers to pick R over B in the first round. Now, if I want to maximize my earnings, I need to switch my strategy and exploit their preference for R by picking B consistently or at least frequently enough to earn the 40$ payoff when they choose R again.

So, for the next round, I will pick {B}. If my opponent sticks with their R choice, I will earn 40$. However, if they try to adapt and change their strategy to B as well, I may have an opportunity to switch back to R and potentially earn 45$ again.

By mixing up my choices based on the opponent's pattern of play and adapting to new information, I aim to maximize my earnings over the long run of 75 rounds.
